Criterion: Criterion 2: Additional factors relating to VI

options.text: No relevant additional factors
Late referral of permanent VI (more than 12 months from presumed onset)
Continuing assessment of VI required e.g. fluctuating condition, deteriorating/degenerative/progressive loss
Recently acquired permanent VI (within the last 6 months)

Criterion: Criterion 3: Impact of the CYP’s VI on language and communication development and on access to learning and the curriculum (particularly English, mathematics and science)

options.text: Expected/better than expected progress that does not need additional input
The learner requires assessment and advice from a QTVI
The learner requires a short-term programme delivered by a QTVI to develop skills that enable access to the curriculum e.g. touch-typing, developing independence and self-advocacy
The learner requires a long-term programme delivered and maintained by a QTVI e.g. Braille
The learner has no issues affecting independent mobility or daily living skills
The learner requires assessment and advice by a Habilitation specialist qualified to work with CYP
The learner needs a structured approach to develop independence, self-organisational skills and functional life skills
The learner requires a short-term programme delivered by a Habilitation specialist

The learner has CVI/complex needs/is non-ambulant (wheelchair)/has developmental mobility or balance and co-ordination issues affecting independent mobility. Requires support from a Habilitation specialist and liaison with an Occupational Therapist or Physiotherapist
The learner requires a long-term programme delivered and maintained by a Habilitation specialist
Key staff/parents/carers have knowledge and understanding of the impact of VI on all key areas
Key staff/parents/carers require additional or continuing training and/or mentoring on VI
Key staff/parents/carers new to VI and require initial intensive training and/or mentoring
Key staff need tuition in Braille/use of specialist equipment

Criterion: Criterion 5.2: Transition support (i.e. change of placement)

options.text: Transition not currently relevant to the CYP
Low contribution required as the service is confident that the learner can make a successful transition with minimal additional support
Moderate contribution due to enhanced transition arrangements
High contribution required as a high level of training is needed and the learner requires a high level of support from the service to make a successful transition

Criterion: Criterion 6: support for effective use of specialist equipment by learner and key staff (may include CCTVs, LVAs, Braille, tactile and speech access and adaptation of print materials)

options.text: No additional assistive technology required
Low level of support including short-term programme
Moderate level of support including short-term programme and some regular monitoring
New user of equipment requiring longer-term programme and refresher programmes
High level of support including Braille equipment

details.title: General principles in the provision of an inclusive visual learning environment
considerations: Signage - clear and well positioned, easily visible, including tactile symbols or Braille
Steps, edges, pillars and other transition points highlighted with yellow paint
Clear panels on doors so people can be seen approaching from the other side
Attention to lighting – provision of blinds to reduce glare
Good classroom management – walkways clear, layout of classroom consistent, resources kept in the same place and appropriately marked with print or tactile markers
Cloakrooms and corridors free of clutter
A distinction between quiet and active areas in the playground and shaded areas for learners with light sensitivity

details.title: General principles in the provision of an inclusive tactile learning environment
considerations: 'Tactile trails’ – dado rails or other textured material at hand height that learners can follow to find the route to a particular location in the school i.e. toilets, dining hall.
Differentiation of floor coverings and areas within the school to indicate a change of environment
Wall displays accessible to touch at child height

Criterion: Criterion 7: Physical learning environment. NB factors affecting the quality of the acoustic and visual environment are outlined in the Appendix at 2.4

options.text: Learning environment which meets appropriate acoustic and visual standards for VI pupils and supports inclusive learning for the VI learner

Learning environment which supports inclusive learning for the VI learner and which will include reasonable adjustments in relation to acoustics, lighting, carpets and blinds and minimal reflections off surfaces

Learning environment which supports aspects of inclusive learning for the VI learner and which will include some reasonable adjustments in relation to acoustics, lighting and visual contrast. (Educational placement requires an informal audit by QTVI)

Learning environment which needs considerable improvement to meet appropriate acoustic and visual standards (e.g. highly reverberant, high level of noise interference, inconsistent room layout, inappropriate lighting, physical hazards). Environment will need to accommodate physical and learning access needs of a Braille user. Educational placement requires a full environmental audit by a Habilitation specialist. A referral to an audiologist may also be needed

options.text: No/minimal impact on personal, social and emotional learning
Low level of impact upon the development of personal, social and emotional learning skills
Moderate level of impact upon the development of personal, social and emotional learning skills

High level of impact upon the development of personal, social and emotional learning skills (e.g. CYP displays a low level of emotional resilience requiring a high level of additional support; long term support required for emotional/personal/social learning needs)
